query: In which year did John Stevens Henslow graduate as the 16th wrangler from St. John's College, Cambridge?
reference_contexts:
["John Stevens Henslow (6 February 1796 – 16 May 1861) was an English Anglican priest, botanist and geologist. He is best remembered as friend and mentor to Charles Darwin.


== Early life ==
Henslow was born at Rochester, Kent, the son of a solicitor John Prentis Henslow, who was the son of John Henslow.
Henslow was educated at St. John's College, Cambridge where he graduated as 16th wrangler in 1818, the year in which Adam Sedgwick became Woodwardian Professor of Geology."]
reference_answer: John Stevens Henslow graduated as the 16th wrangler in 1818 from St. John's College, Cambridge.

query: What role did John Stevens Henslow play in Charles Darwin's career, and how did he influence Darwin's work on evolution?
reference_contexts:
['John Stevens Henslow (6 February 1796 – 16 May 1861) was an English Anglican priest, botanist and geologist. He is best remembered as friend and mentor to Charles Darwin.


== Early life ==
Henslow was born at Rochester, Kent, the son of a solicitor John Prentis Henslow, who was the son of John Henslow.
Henslow was educated at St. John's College, Cambridge where he graduated as 16th wrangler in 1818, the year in which Adam Sedgwick became Woodwardian Professor of Geology.


== Early career ==
Henslow graduated in 1818. He already had a passion for natural history from his childhood, which largely influenced his career, and he accompanied Sedgwick in 1819 on a tour in the Isle of Wight where he learned his first lessons in geology. He also studied chemistry under Professor James Cumming and mineralogy under Edward Daniel Clarke. In the autumn of 1819 he made valuable observations on the geology of the Isle of Man (Trans. Geol. Soc., 1821) and in 1820 and 1821 he investigated the geology of parts of Anglesey, the results being printed in the first volume of the Transactions of the Cambridge Philosophical Society (1822). The Philosophical Society was founded in November 1819 by a group at Cambridge with Professors Farish, Lee, and Sedgwick and Henslow (at that time not yet a professor). The idea and initial impetus for the society originated from Sedgwick and Henslow.
Meanwhile, Henslow had studied mineralogy with considerable zeal, so that on the death of Clarke he was in 1822 appointed professor of mineralogy in the University of Cambridge. Two years later he took holy orders. Botany, however, had claimed much of his attention, and to this science he became more and more attached, so that he gladly resigned the chair of mineralogy in 1827, two years after becoming professor of botany. As a teacher both in the classroom and in the field he was eminently successful. He was a correspondent of John James Audubon who in 1829 named Henslow's sparrow (Centronyx henslowii) after him.
From 1821 Henslow had begun organising a herbarium of British flora, supplementing his own collecting with a network which expanded over time to include his friends and family, and the botanists William Jackson Hooker and John Hutton Balfour, as well as about 30 of his students. As a mineralogist he had used Haüy's laws of crystallography to analyse complex crystals as transformations of "the primitive form of the species" of crystal, and when he moved to botany in 1825 he sought similarly precise laws to group plant varieties into species, often including as varieties plants that respected taxonomists had ranked as separate species. He followed the understanding of the time that species were fixed as created but could vary within limits, and hoped to analyse these limits of variation. By a method he called "collation", Henslow prepared sheets with several plant specimens, each labelled with the collector, date and place of collection, comparing the specimens to show the variation within the species. His A Catalogue of British Plants was first published in October 1829, and became a set book for his lecture course.
Henslow is remembered as friend and mentor to his pupil Charles Darwin, and for inspiring him with a passion for natural history. The two met in 1828. Earlier that year, Darwin joined the course and along with other students helped to collect plants of Cambridgeshire. Henslow became his tutor, and it was not long before he marked out Darwin as a promising student. In 1830 Henslow experimented on varying the conditions of garden grown wild plants to produce various forms of the plant. In 1835 Henslow published Principles of Descriptive and Physiological Botany as a textbook based on this lecture course.
In the summer of 1831 Henslow was offered a place as naturalist to sail aboard the survey ship HMS Beagle on a two-year voyage to survey South America, but his wife dissuaded him from accepting. Seeing a perfect opportunity for his protégé, Henslow wrote to the ship's captain Robert Fitzroy telling him that Darwin was the ideal man to join the expedition team. During the voyage, Darwin corresponded with Henslow, and collected plants with him in mind. In particular, when first arriving at the Galápagos Islands Darwin noted "I certainly recognize S America in Ornithology, would a botanist?", and went on to collect plant specimens carefully labelled by island and date. He also labelled the mockingbirds he caught, and initially thought these were varieties but while arranging these bird specimens on the last lap of the voyage he began wondering if they could be species, a possibility which would "undermine the stability of Species". Henslow's teaching continued to influence Darwin's work on evolution.
Besides Darwin, other famous students of Henslow included Miles Joseph Berkeley, Cardale Babington, Leonard Jenyns, Richard Thomas Lowe and William Hallowes Miller.']
reference_answer:
John Stevens Henslow played a pivotal role as both a mentor and friend to Charles Darwin, significantly influencing his career and work on evolution. Their relationship began when they met in 1828 at the University of Cambridge, where Henslow was teaching botany. Recognizing Darwin's potential early on, Henslow marked him out as a promising student.

Henslow's influence extended beyond formal education; he inspired Darwin with a passion for natural history and provided guidance that shaped his scientific pursuits. One of Henslow’s most significant contributions to Darwin's career was recommending him for the position of naturalist aboard HMS Beagle, despite Henslow himself being offered the role. This recommendation led to Darwin embarking on the two-year voyage around South America, which became crucial in developing his ideas about evolution.

During the voyage, Darwin maintained correspondence with Henslow and collected plant specimens with Henslow's expertise in mind. The observations and collections made during this journey, particularly at the Galápagos Islands, were instrumental in shaping Darwin’s thoughts on species variation and natural selection. Henslow's teachings continued to influence Darwin as he began questioning the stability of species based on his findings.

Overall, Henslow's mentorship provided Darwin with both scientific knowledge and opportunities that were critical in formulating his groundbreaking theories on evolution.

query: Describe the contributions of John Stevens Henslow to botany, particularly his method called "collation" and its purpose.
reference_contexts:
['John Stevens Henslow (6 February 1796 – 16 May 1861) was an English Anglican priest, botanist and geologist. He is best remembered as friend and mentor to Charles Darwin.


== Early life ==
Henslow was born at Rochester, Kent, the son of a solicitor John Prentis Henslow, who was the son of John Henslow.
Henslow was educated at St. John's College, Cambridge where he graduated as 16th wrangler in 1818, the year in which Adam Sedgwick became Woodwardian Professor of Geology.


== Early career ==
Henslow graduated in 1818. He already had a passion for natural history from his childhood, which largely influenced his career, and he accompanied Sedgwick in 1819 on a tour in the Isle of Wight where he learned his first lessons in geology. He also studied chemistry under Professor James Cumming and mineralogy under Edward Daniel Clarke. In the autumn of 1819 he made valuable observations on the geology of the Isle of Man (Trans. Geol. Soc., 1821) and in 1820 and 1821 he investigated the geology of parts of Anglesey, the results being printed in the first volume of the Transactions of the Cambridge Philosophical Society (1822). The Philosophical Society was founded in November 1819 by a group at Cambridge with Professors Farish, Lee, and Sedgwick and Henslow (at that time not yet a professor). The idea and initial impetus for the society originated from Sedgwick and Henslow.

Two years later he took holy orders. As a teacher both in the classroom and in the field he was eminently successful. He was a correspondent of John James Audubon who in 1829 named Henslow's sparrow (Centronyx henslowii) after him.
From 1821 Henslow had begun organising a herbarium of British flora, supplementing his own collecting with a network which expanded over time to include his friends and family, and the botanists William Jackson Hooker and John Hutton Balfour, as well as about 30 of his students. As a mineralogist he had used Haüy's laws of crystallography to analyse complex crystals as transformations of "the primitive form of the species" of crystal, and when he moved to botany in 1825 he sought similarly precise laws to group plant varieties into species, often including as varieties plants that respected taxonomists had ranked as separate species. He followed the understanding of the time that species were fixed as created but could vary within limits, and hoped to analyse these limits of variation. By a method he called "collation", Henslow prepared sheets with several plant specimens, each labelled with the collector, date and place of collection, comparing the specimens to show the variation within the species. His A Catalogue of British Plants was first published in October 1829, and became a set book for his lecture course.
Henslow is remembered as friend and mentor to his pupil Charles Darwin, and for inspiring him with a passion for natural history. The two met in 1828. Earlier that year, Darwin joined the course and along with other students helped to collect plants of Cambridgeshire. Henslow became his tutor, and it was not long before he marked out Darwin as a promising student. In 1830 Henslow experimented on varying the conditions of garden grown wild plants to produce various forms of the plant. In 1835 Henslow published Principles of Descriptive and Physiological Botany as a textbook based on this lecture course.
In the summer of 1831 Henslow was offered a place as naturalist to sail aboard the survey ship HMS Beagle on a two-year voyage to survey South America, but his wife dissuaded him from accepting. Seeing a perfect opportunity for his protégé, Henslow wrote to the ship's captain Robert Fitzroy telling him that Darwin was the ideal man to join the expedition team. During the voyage, Darwin corresponded with Henslow, and collected plants with him in mind. In particular, when first arriving at the Galápagos Islands Darwin noted "I certainly recognize S America in Ornithology, would a botanist?", and went on to collect plant specimens carefully labelled by island and date. He also labelled the mockingbirds he caught, and initially thought these were varieties but while arranging these bird specimens on the last lap of the voyage he began wondering if they could be species, a possibility which would "undermine the stability of Species". Henslow's teaching continued to influence Darwin's work on evolution.
Besides Darwin, other famous students of Henslow included Miles Joseph Berkeley, Cardale Babington, Leonard Jenyns, Richard Thomas Lowe and William Hallowes Miller.']
reference_answer:
John Stevens Henslow made significant contributions to botany through both his teaching methods and scientific approaches. One notable contribution was his development of a method known as "collation." This method involved preparing sheets with multiple specimens of the same plant species, each labeled with details such as the collector's name, date, and place of collection. The purpose of collation was to systematically compare these specimens to observe variations within a species.

Henslow aimed to analyze the limits of variation within species by using this method. At the time, it was generally understood that species were fixed entities created with certain inherent variability. Henslow's approach sought to identify and categorize these variations precisely, often including plants that other taxonomists might have classified as separate species.

Through collation, Henslow hoped to establish more precise laws for grouping plant varieties into species, similar to how he had previously applied Haüy's laws of crystallography in mineralogy. This method not only contributed to the scientific understanding of botanical classification but also influenced his students, including Charles Darwin, who later developed groundbreaking ideas on evolution.

Additionally, Henslow's work extended beyond collation; he organized a herbarium of British flora and published "A Catalogue of British Plants" in 1829. This publication became an essential resource for his lecture course and further established his influence in the field of botany.

reference_answer:
John Stevens Henslow's early education and career choices were deeply influenced by his passion for natural history, which is evident from several key aspects of his academic pursuits and professional appointments.

1. **Education at St. John’s College, Cambridge**: Henslow was educated at St. John’s College, where he graduated as the 16th wrangler in 1818. This achievement indicates a strong foundation in mathematics and science, which are essential for studying natural history.

2. **Interest in Geology**: His passion for natural history began early in his life and significantly influenced his career choices. In 1819, Henslow accompanied Adam Sedgwick on a tour of the Isle of Wight to learn geology, marking one of his first formal engagements with geological studies. This experience laid the groundwork for his future contributions to geology.

3. **Studies in Chemistry and Mineralogy**: Henslow furthered his education by studying chemistry under Professor James Cumming and mineralogy under Edward Daniel Clarke. These disciplines are closely related to natural history, as they involve understanding the composition and structure of natural materials.

4. **Professional Appointments**:
   - In 1822, following the death of Edward Daniel Clarke, Henslow was appointed professor of mineralogy at the University of Cambridge. This appointment reflects his expertise and passion for studying minerals.
   - Two years later, he took holy orders but continued to pursue his interest in natural history by transitioning from mineralogy to botany. In 1827, he became a professor of botany, indicating a shift towards plant sciences.

5. **Botanical Work**: Henslow's work in botany included organizing a herbarium of British flora and developing methods like "collation" to study plant variation. His efforts culminated in the publication of *A Catalogue of British Plants* in 1829, which became an essential resource for his lecture course.

6. **Influence on Students**: Henslow's passion for natural history was also reflected in his mentorship of students like Charles Darwin, whom he inspired with a love for natural sciences. His teaching methods and experimental work in botany influenced many future scientists.

Overall, John Stevens Henslow’s early education and career choices were deeply intertwined with his passion for natural history, as evidenced by his studies in geology, chemistry, mineralogy, and botany, along with his professional roles that allowed him to explore these fields further.

query: What significant change occurred in Henslow's life when he was appointed as rector of Hitcham, Suffolk in 1837, and how did it impact his involvement with Cambridge University?
reference_contexts:
["== A country clergyman ==
In 1833, Henslow was appointed vicar of Cholsey-cum-Moulsford in Berkshire (now Oxfordshire). He continued to live in Cambridge, only visiting the parish during vacations; he appointed a curate to conduct services and parish business during term-time.
However, his appointment in 1837 to the remunerative Crown living at Hitcham, Suffolk marked a turning-point in his life. This time, in 1839, he moved to the parish, and as rector of Hitcham he lived at the rectory. He worked there, endearing himself to all who knew him, until the end of his life. His energies were devoted to the improvement of his parishioners, but his influence was felt far and wide. Botany at Cambridge suffered, attendance at lectures fell, and we have records of complaints made within the university. Henslow did not resign his chair, and continued to give lectures, set and mark exams, and take part in university affairs. Nevertheless, his influence there was naturally much reduced.
Henslow's work in Hitcham, over and above the normal duties of a Rector, can be summarised as follows:

1. The Parish School and other charities. Hitcham was a poor parish, and most people would have been illiterate. Education had to be paid for, and so Henslow both raised funds and donated his own money to support a school. The school was founded in 1841, and Henslow himself gave a series of volunteer classes on Monday afternoons for some of the older children. The botanical curriculum was printed.The botany taught in this school had effects throughout Britain, because important people at the centre, such as Prince Albert and Lyon Playfair kept in touch and rightly regarded Henslow as an authority on the subject.
2. Adult education in the Village. The Hitcham Labourers' and Mechanics' Horticultural Society was the vehicle used by Henslow to 'improve' the labouring and agricultural workers in the village and its surrounds.  Competitions, shows and excursions were the attractions, and the intent was practical, to improve agriculture by educating the parishioners. Henslow made use of gifts and facilities provided by his friends. Advances such as made by Justus von Liebig in Germany, who began to apply chemistry to the needs of agriculture, had not yet become widely utilised.
3. Museums. The town of Ipswich is twelve miles from Hitcham. As a result of his Cambridge experiences, Henslow believed in the value of museums as vehicles for education. Ipswich Museum was established in 1847 as a natural history museum and owed much to Henslow, who was elected its President in 1850.
Alongside this work he remained an inquiring scientist at heart. In 1843 he discovered nodules of coprolitic origin in the Red Crag at Felixstowe in Suffolk, and two years later he called attention to those also in the Cambridge Greensand and remarked that they might be of use in agriculture. Although Henslow derived no benefit, these discoveries led to the establishment of the phosphate industry in Suffolk and Cambridgeshire; and the works proved lucrative until the introduction of foreign phosphates.
In 1851, Carl Ludwig Blume named a genus of flowering plants belonging to the family Santalaceae, from Indo-China as Henslowia, in honour of Henslow.
Henslow died on 16 May 1861 at Hitcham.


== Family ==
Henslow married Harriet Jenyns (1797–1857), daughter of George Leonard Jenyns and sister of Leonard Jenyns on 16 December 1823. Their eldest daughter Frances Harriet married Joseph Dalton Hooker, and their youngest daughter, Anne, became a botanical artist. Their sons included George Henslow (1835–1925), who became the Royal Horticultural Society's Professor of Botany and the first President of the Churchmen's Union for the Advancement of Liberal Religious Thought."]
reference_answer:
When Henslow was appointed as rector of Hitcham, Suffolk in 1837, a significant change occurred in his life. Unlike his previous appointment at Cholsey-cum-Moulsford where he continued to live in Cambridge and only visited the parish during vacations, this time he moved to Hitcham in 1839 and lived there permanently as rector. This relocation marked a turning point because it led him to devote much of his energy to improving his parishioners' lives.

Despite continuing his academic duties at Cambridge University—such as giving lectures, setting and marking exams, and participating in university affairs—his influence within the university naturally diminished due to his physical absence from Cambridge. Attendance at his botany lectures fell, and there were complaints about his reduced involvement in university activities. Nonetheless, Henslow maintained a connection with both his parish work and academic responsibilities until the end of his life.

query: Describe the role of the Hitcham Labourers' and Mechanics' Horticultural Society in Henslow's efforts to improve agriculture and education among parishioners.
reference_contexts:
["== A country clergyman ==

reference_answer:
The Hitcham Labourers' and Mechanics' Horticultural Society played a significant role in Henslow's efforts to enhance both agriculture and education among the parishioners of Hitcham. This society served as a practical vehicle for "improving" the laboring and agricultural workers within the village and its surrounding areas. The primary intent behind this initiative was educational, aiming to elevate agricultural practices by educating the local community.

Henslow utilized various methods through the society to engage parishioners in learning and development. These included organizing competitions, shows, and excursions that were designed not only as attractions but also as practical means of imparting knowledge about better agricultural techniques. The society provided a platform for hands-on learning experiences, which was crucial at a time when theoretical advances in agriculture, such as those made by Justus von Liebig in Germany, had yet to be widely adopted.

Moreover, Henslow leveraged gifts and facilities from his friends to support the activities of the society, thereby enriching the resources available for educational purposes. Through these efforts, he aimed to foster a more informed and skilled agricultural workforce, ultimately contributing to the improvement of local agriculture in Hitcham. The society thus became an integral part of Henslow's broader mission to uplift his parishioners through education and practical application of knowledge.

query: How did Henslow contribute to the establishment of Ipswich Museum, and what was its significance in terms of educational value?
reference_contexts:
["== A country clergyman ==

The Hitcham Labourers' and Mechanics' Horticultural Society was the vehicle used by Henslow to 'improve' the labouring and agricultural workers in the village and its surrounds.  Competitions, shows and excursions were the attractions, and the intent was practical, to improve agriculture by educating the parishioners. Henslow made use of gifts and facilities provided by his friends. Advances such as made by Justus von Liebig in Germany, who began to apply chemistry to the needs of agriculture, had not yet become widely utilised.
3. Museums. The town of Ipswich is twelve miles from Hitcham. As a result of his Cambridge experiences, Henslow believed in the value of museums as vehicles for education. Ipswich Museum was established in 1847 as a natural history museum and owed much to Henslow, who was elected its President in 1850.
Alongside this work he remained an inquiring scientist at heart. In 1843 he discovered nodules of coprolitic origin in the Red Crag at Felixstowe in Suffolk, and two years later he called attention to those also in the Cambridge Greensand and remarked that they might be of use in agriculture. Although Henslow derived no benefit, these discoveries led to the establishment of the phosphate industry in Suffolk and Cambridgeshire; and the works proved lucrative until the introduction of foreign phosphates.
In 1851, Carl Ludwig Blume named a genus of flowering plants belonging to the family Santalaceae, from Indo-China as Henslowia, in honour of Henslow.
Henslow died on 16 May 1861 at Hitcham.


== Family ==
Henslow married Harriet Jenyns (1797–1857), daughter of George Leonard Jenyns and sister of Leonard Jenyns on 16 December 1823. Their eldest daughter Frances Harriet married Joseph Dalton Hooker, and their youngest daughter, Anne, became a botanical artist. Their sons included George Henslow (1835–1925), who became the Royal Horticultural Society's Professor of Botany and the first President of the Churchmen's Union for the Advancement of Liberal Religious Thought."]
reference_answer:
John Stevens Henslow contributed significantly to the establishment of Ipswich Museum by leveraging his experiences and beliefs about the educational value of museums. As someone who had a deep appreciation for natural history and education, Henslow recognized that museums could serve as important vehicles for public learning and engagement with science.

Henslow's involvement in the creation of Ipswich Museum began when it was established in 1847 as a natural history museum. His influence on the museum was substantial; he became its President in 1850, indicating his active role in guiding its development and ensuring that it fulfilled its educational mission. Henslow's commitment to education is evident from his efforts to improve the lives of his parishioners through various initiatives, such as founding a school with a botanical curriculum and promoting adult education.

The significance of Ipswich Museum in terms of educational value lies in its role as an accessible resource for learning about natural history. By providing exhibits and collections related to natural science, the museum offered opportunities for self-education and inspiration to both locals and visitors. It served as a platform for disseminating scientific knowledge and fostering curiosity among the general public, aligning with Henslow's broader educational goals.

Overall, Henslow's contribution to Ipswich Museum was rooted in his belief that museums could democratize education by making scientific knowledge available to all, thereby enhancing public understanding of natural history and its relevance to everyday life.

query: On what date did John Stevens Henslow marry Harriet Jenyns, and how was she related to Leonard Jenyns?
reference_contexts:
['== Family ==
Henslow married Harriet Jenyns (1797–1857), daughter of George Leonard Jenyns and sister of Leonard Jenyns on 16 December 1823. Their eldest daughter Frances Harriet married Joseph Dalton Hooker, and their youngest daughter, Anne, became a botanical artist. Their sons included George Henslow (1835–1925), who became the Royal Horticultural Society's Professor of Botany and the first President of the Churchmen's Union for the Advancement of Liberal Religious Thought.


== Selected publications ==
Henslow, John Stevens (1822). "Geological Description of Anglesea". Transactions of the Cambridge Philosophical Society. 1: 359–452.
Henslow, John Stevens. (1823). A Syllabus of a Course of Lectures on Mineralogy. Deighton (reissued by Cambridge University Press, 2009; ISBN 978-1-108-00201-1)
Henslow, John Stevens. (1829; 2nd ed. 1835). A Catalogue of British Plants.
Henslow, John Stevens. (1835). The Principles of Descriptive and Physiological Botany. Longman, Rees, Orme, Brown & Green (reissued by Cambridge University Press, 2009; ISBN 978-1-108-00186-1)
Henslow, John Stevens. (1846). The Teaching of Science in Cambridge. Metcalfe and Palmer (reissued by Cambridge University Press, 2009; ISBN 978-1-108-00200-4)
Henslow, John Stevens. (1856). A Dictionary of Botanical Terms. Groombridge (reissued by Cambridge University Press, 2009; ISBN 978-1-108-00131-1)
Henslow, John Stevens, and Skepper, E. (1866). Flora of Suffolk

reference_answer:
John Stevens Henslow married Harriet Jenyns on December 16, 1823. Harriet Jenyns was the daughter of George Leonard Jenyns and the sister of Leonard Jenyns.

**Explanation:**

The context information provided states that John Stevens Henslow married Harriet Jenyns on December 16, 1823. It also mentions that Harriet was the daughter of George Leonard Jenyns and the sister of Leonard Jenyns. This establishes both the date of their marriage and Harriet's relationship to Leonard Jenyns.
